details.title: Testing the untestable: reliability in the 21st century

authors.affiliation: Statistics Group, Los Alamos, NM, USA

p: Thomas R. Bennett was a Statistician in the Statistics Group at Los Alamos in 1975 until his death in 2000. In 1999, he received the prestigious R&D 100 Award for development of the PREDICT reliability methodology. He received the Los Alamos Achievement Award in 1997 and has published in journals such as Technometrics, Journal of the American Statistical Association, and Journal of Quality Technology. He was a coauthor of the paper receiving the 1992 American Society for Quality Control Brumbaugh Award. He was a member of the American Statistical Association and the American Society for Quality Control.

authors.name: T.R. Bennett

p: Jane M. Booker is a Statistician in the Engineering Analysis Group at Los Alamos National Laboratory. She is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association and received the prestigious R&D 100 Award in 1999 for the development of the PREDICT reliability methodology. She is a former group leader of the Statistics Group at Los Alamos, and has co-authored a book with Mary Meyer, Eliciting and Analyzing Expert Judgment: A Practical Guide, and co-edited a book to be published by ASA-SIAM on Fuzzy Logic and Probability Applications.

details.abstract: As science and technology become increasingly sophisticated, government and industry are relying more and more on science's advanced methods to determine reliability. Unfortunately, political, economic, time, and other constraints imposed by the real world, inhibit the ability of researchers to calculate reliability efficiently and accurately. Because of such constraints, reliability must undergo an evolutionary change. The first step in this evolution is to re-interpret the concept so that it meets the new century's needs. The next step is to quantify reliability using both empirical methods and auxiliary data sources, such as expert knowledge, corporate memory, and mathematical modeling and simulation.

references.title: Decision analysis in project management: An overview

context.text: Although decision trees are not a new idea (for an overview of related literature, see [5] and [6]), they remain a powerful characterization of the normative approach to decision making.

links.abstract: The authors include very general topical summaries in utility theory, mathematical programming, statistical methods, scoring and ranking methods, and cognitive science. The emphasis is on the role of decision analysis in the management of research and development projects. The intent is to provide nonspecialists with a broad survey of the many facets of decision theory.

references.text: J. M. Booker, M. C. Bryson, "Decision analysis in project management: An overview", IEEE Trans. Eng. Manage., vol. EM-32, no. 1, 1985.

references.title: Scientific Reasoning: The Bayesian Approach

context.text: With so many theories, why should anyone subscribe to the calculus of probability? In a book [16], several contributors attempt to answer this very question; contributors range from gamblers and philosophers to mathematicians, decision theorists, behavioral scientists, and experts in artificial intelligence and knowledge acquisition.
It has been demonstrated (e.g., [16]) that to maximize winnings (determine the most accurate probability of success), the betting coefficients must follow the calculus of probability.

references.text: <comment>Please verify initial(s).</comment> Howson, P. Urbach, Scientific Reasoning: The Bayesian Approach, 1989, Open Court.

references.title: PREDICT&#821A new approach to product development

context.text: In this paper, reinterpretation of reliability advocates the use of all data on the list, and its success has been demonstrated [28].2 2PREDICT (Performance and Reliability Evaluation with Diverse Information Combination and Tracking) is an integrated reliability methodology that combines all available information, with appropriate uncertainties attached, relating to the system's performance.

references.text: M. A. Meyer, J. M. Booker, T. R. Bennent, "PREDICT&#821A new approach to product development", vol. 41, pp. 161, Sep. 1999.
